The NAEB has conducted 26 seminars and regional meetings sup¬
ported in whole, or in part, by Kellogg Foundation or NAEB funds. (For
a listing, see Appendix 8.)
As indicated earlier in this report, the self-supporting seminar
held at Purdue University in the summer of 1958, as an experiment in
this type of financing, was the first such venture to be undertaken by
the NAEB, Although a limited number attended (due, probably, to the
fact that participants were required to pay a $100 tuition fee in addition
to paying their own expenses), the meeting was highly successful in that
the participants indicated that a meeting of this sort was precisely in
an area in which they needed help. All participants encouraged the NAEB
to conduct as many such seminars as possible. We believe that even¬
tually a program of professional advancement can be worked out which
will enable the NAEB to provide such training and also realize some income
to help underwrite other services.
